Work with recurring calendar events in R

James Laird-Smith

2019-08-10

Source: vignettes/intro.Rmd
intro.Rmd

Recurring calendar events are very common in everyday life. Some are simple and therefore easy to program with. Others however are not and are difficult to understand and exceeding difficult to program with.

The objective of scheduler is to make working with these recurring calendar events a little easier. By providing an intutive set of building blocks and a means of combining them together, users will be able to create and use schedules of arbitrary complexity.

To start with, we will need to laod the following packages:

library(lubridate)
library(scheduler)
library(magrittr)

scheduler builds atop the lubridate package, which provides various accessor functions for different elements of a date. For example, if I wanted to know which day in a year a particlar date fell upon, lubridate provides a function to access it, called yday():

lubridate::yday(as.Date("2000-01-01"))
#> [1] 1
lubridate::yday(as.Date("2000-12-31"))
#> [1] 366

lubridate provides a whole set of these accessor functions. For example, mday() to access the day of the month a date falls on, wday() for the day of the week, month() for the month of the date, year() for the year of the date etc.

first_day_millenium <- as.Date("2000-01-01")

lubridate::mday(first_day_millenium)
#> [1] 1
lubridate::wday(first_day_millenium)
#> [1] 7
lubridate::month(first_day_millenium)
#> [1] 1

scheduler fufils a different purpose, but uses the same naming scheme. Whereas lubridate provides accessors to elements of a particualr date, the purpose of scheduler is to let you specify the element of the schedule.

Developed by James Laird-Smith.
